text: The Epstein-Barr virus <extra_id_0> latent membrane protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is essential for the transformation of B lymphocytes into lymphoblastoid cell lines .

Previous data are consistent with a model that <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a constitutively activated receptor that transduces signals for transformation through its carboxyl-terminal cytoplasmic tail .
One transformation effector site ( TES1 ) , located within the membrane proximal 45 residues of the cytoplasmic tail , constitutively engages tumor necrosis factor receptor - associated factors .

Signals from TES1 are sufficient to drive initial proliferation of infected resting B lymphocytes , but most lymphoblastoid cells infected with a virus that does not express the 155 residues beyond TES1 fail to grow as long-term cell lines .

We now find that mutating two tyrosines to an isoleucine at the carboxyl end of the cytoplasmic tail cripples the ability of EBV to cause lymphoblastoid cell outgrowth , thereby marking a second transformation effector site , TES2 .

A yeast two-hybrid screen identified TES2 interacting proteins , including the <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated death domain protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TRADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
<extra_id_0> TRADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was the only protein that interacted with wild-type TES2 and not with isoleucine-mutated TES2 .

text: In transfection assays , <extra_id_0> TRADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TES2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synergistically mediated high-level NF-kappaB activation .

These results indicate that <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> appropriates <extra_id_0> TRADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to enable efficient long-term lymphoblastoid cell outgrowth .
High-level NF-kappaB activation also appears to be a critical component of long-term outgrowth .
